questions.text: Match the following signs with respective lobar collapse
questions.solution:
• Golden's S sign is seen with right upper lobe collapse. The Golden S-sign is seen on frontal chest radiographs. In the most common situation, the appearance is that of right upper lobar collapse (the right upper lobe appearing dense and shifting medially and upwards) with a central mass expanding the hilum. These two changes together form a reverse S-shape.
  • Luftsichel sign is seen with left upper lobe collapse. The Luftsichel sign is seen in some patients with left upper lobe collapse. It appears as a curvilinear air density in frontal chest X-ray, between the mediastinum and the collapsed left upper lobe, due to hyperinflation of the superior segment of the left lower lobe.
  • Flat waist sign is seen with left lower lobe collapse. The Luftsichel sign is seen in some patients with left upper lobe collapse. It appears as a curvilinear air density in frontal chest X-ray, between the mediastinum and the collapsed left upper lobe, due to hyperinflation of the superior segment of the left lower lobe.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 2281

questions.text: For detection of small pneumothorax, a CXR should be taken in?
questions.solution:
For detection of small pneumothorax, an expiratory film should be ordered as in expiration lung will be collapsed and contrast between the pneumothorax and lung can be easily identified.

Reference: Thoracic imaging-Pulmonary and cardiovascular radiology edition 3 page 694

questions.text: Left border of heart on CXR is formed by?
questions.solution:
Right border of mediastinum is formed by SVC, RA and IVC.

Left border of mediastinum is formed by LA and LV.

Reference: Thoracic Imaging Pulmonary and Cardiovascular Radiology edition 3, page 41

questions.text: The following CT image is characteristic of which disease?
questions.solution:
The given image shows crazy-paving pattern which is characteristic of PAP. Pulmonary alveolar proteinosis (PAP) is a lung disease characterized by an abnormal intra-alveolar accumulation of surfactant-derived lipo-proteinaceous material.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 2379

choices.text: Enlargement of pretracheal and paratracheal lymphnodes
Dilation of great arteries during pregnancy

questions.text: Thickening of right paratracheal stripe on frontal CXR is suggestive of?
questions.solution:
• Right paratracheal stripe is a thin line of contact between right lung and right tracheal wall, below the thoracic inlet and above the azygos vein.
  • Its thickening is seen in enlargement of pre-tracheal and paratracheal lymph nodes

Reference: Thoracic Imaging Pulmonary and Cardiovascular Radiology edition 3 page 51

questions.text: On myocardial perfusion imaging, bright area represents?
questions.solution:
• Myocardial perfusion study-Gadolinium is injected intravenously as a tight bolus during pharmacologic stress. The pharmacologic stress for the myocardium is achieved by slow IV injection of adenosine 140 microgram per kg body weight.
  • The sequence used is T1-weighted GRE sequence like turbo FLASH with high temporal resolution. Low signal areas of under perfusion on these images correspond with regions of ischemia or infarct.

Reference: MRI made easy edition 2, page 180

questions.text: An asymptomatic patient underwent a CXR. On doing a CXR, it was observed that there was a soft tissue density on right side of the heart. On doing a CT scan, the following image was obtained. What is the most probable diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
• Pericardial cysts are remnants of defective embryological development of the pericardium. They are most often asymptomatic and discovered incidentally on chest radiographs or CT.
  • The typical location of pericardial cysts is the pericardiophrenic angle, much more common on the right but can be located throughout the mediastinum.
  • On CT, these cysts are seen as non-enhancing well circumscribed ovoid, fluid density masses adjacent to the pericardium.

Reference: Mc-Graw Hill speciality Board review Radiology pg 322

questions.text: What is shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
• Thoracic aortic aneurysm is defined as localized or diffuse dilatation of more than 50% of the normal diameter of the thoracic aorta. In the thoracic aorta, more than 4.5 cm is considered aneurysmal.
  • CT is a common and reliable modality performed for initial diagnosis of aneurysm, preoperative assessment, and postoperative surveillance. Above image shows thoracic aortic aneurysm.

Reference: Mc-Graw Hill speciality Board review Radiology page 334

questions.text: A patient with known case of RHD presented with dyspnea. On doing a CXR, following image was obtained. What is shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
• The classic radiographic feature of rheumatic MV disease is left atrial enlargement and left atrial appendage enlargement. Left atrial enlargement on chest radiograph is seen as double density through the heart.
  • Displacement of the left main bronchus, and occasionally the esophagus posteriorly, is best seen on lateral radiographs.
  • Left ventricular enlargement is seen in significant mitral regurgitation but is not common in pure mitral stenosis. Curvilinear calcification in the wall of the left atrium or the thrombus lining the atrial wall can be seen in long-standing MV disease.

Reference: Mc-Graw Hill speciality Board review Radiology pg 307

questions.text: Gooseneck deformity is seen in?
questions.solution:
p>Imaging signs of various congenita anomalies



Reference: Mc-Graw Hill speciality Board review Radiology page 293

questions.text: What is shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
• The subarachnoid spaces (SASs) are CSF-filled cavities that lie between the arachnoid and the pia.
  • Hemorrhage into the SAS is known as subarchnoid hemorrhage (SAH).
  • Sometimes, blood in the SAS is refluxed into the cerebral ventricles, producing secondary intraventricular hemorrhage.
  • The typical location of SAH (basal cisterns and sylvian and inferior interhemispheric fissures). The gross appearance of an SAH is typically characterized by blood-filled basal cisterns.

Reference: Osborn Brain edition 2 Brain edition 2 pg 123

questions.text: A patient presented with headache followed by loss of consciousness. On doing an MRI, the following image was obtained. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Cerebral amyloid disease encompasses a heterogeneous group of biochemically and genetically diverse CNS disorders. The most common is an age related micro-vasculopathy termed cerebral amyloid angiopathy (CAA), also known as congophilic angiopathy.
  • CAA is caused by the accumulation of aggregated Aβ in small cerebral vessels. These deposits accumulate in the abluminal portion of the muscular layer and adventitia of cerebral arterioles and capillaries, causing progressive disruption of the neurovascular unit.
    Failure to clear Aβ from the brain has two major consequences: (1) intracranial hemorrhages associated with rupture of Aβ-laden vessels in CAA and (2) altered neuronal function caused by pathologic accumulation of Aβ and other soluble metabolites in AD. The most frequent vascular abnormality seen in AD is CAA.
  • NECT scans in patients with acute manifestations of CAA typically show a hyperdense lobar hematoma with varying peripheral edema. Multiple irregular confluent white matter hypointensities together with generalized volume loss are common. Enhancement on CECT is rare in cerebral amyloid disease and occurs only if a focal mass ("amyloidoma") or ABRA is present. Occasionally, patients with CAA can present with so-called convexal subarachnoid hemorrhage (cSAH) (10-68). In cSAH, the basal cisterns appear normal, but one or more adjacent convexity sulci demonstrate curvilinear hyperdensity consistent with blood.

Reference: Osborn Brain edition 2 Brain edition 2 pg 317

questions.text: A patient suspected to have diffuse axonal injury following trauma. Which of the following investigation is used for diffuse axonal injury?
questions.solution:
• DAI is also known as traumatic axonal stretch injury. DAI typically causes much more significant impairment compared with extracerebral hematomas and cortical contusions. DAI often causes immediate loss of consciousness, which may be transient (in the case of mild TBI) or progress to coma.
  • As most DAIs are non-hemorrhagic, T1 scans are often normal, especially in the early stages of TBI. T2WI and FLAIR may show hyperintense foci in the subcortical white matter and corpus callosum.
  • T2* scans are very sensitive to the microbleeds of DAI and typically show multifocal ovoid and linear hypointensities. DWI may show restricted diffusion, particularly within the corpus callosum. Whole-brain tractography (DTI) may be useful in depicting white matter disruption.

Reference: Osborn Brain edition 2 Brain edition 2 pg 45

questions.text: The gold standard investigation for aneurysm is?
questions.solution:
• CTA is positive in 95% of an SAH cases if the "culprit" aneurysm is 2 mm or larger (6-5B).
  • Although DSA is still considered the gold standard for detecting and delineating aneurysm angioarchitecture, many patients with an SAH and positive CTA undergo surgical clipping without DSA.

Reference: Osborn Brain edition 2 Brain edition 2 pg 127

questions.text: 'Empty delta' sign is seen in?
questions.solution:
• Cerebral dural sinus thrombosis (DST) is defined as thrombotic occlusion of one or more intracranial venous sinuses.
  • DST can occur either in isolation or in combination with cortical and/or deep venous occlusions.
  • CVT predominantly affects women. CECT scans show an "empty delta" sign caused by enhancing dura surrounding non-enhancing thrombus.

Reference: Osborn Brain edition 2 Brain edition 2 pg 262

questions.text: X-rays are produced by stopping high energy electrons at an anode target made of ?
questions.solution:
• X-rays and gamma rays are electromagnetic radiations. X-rays are produced by stopping high-energy electrons in a tungsten target.
  • X-rays are emitted in a continuous spectrum (bremsstrahlung) with a maximum energy equal to the peak accelerating potential of the X-ray tube and at discrete energies dependent on the binding energies of electrons in the target atom.
  • The X-ray beam is filtered (usually with aluminium) to remove low-energy photons that contribute to patient dose but not to the image.

Reference: Farr's physics for medical imaging page no 20

questions.text: X-rays were discovered by ?
questions.solution:
• Wilhelm C Roentgen (1845-1923) was a German physicist who is celebrated globally for his discovery of x-rays on 8 November 1895.
  • On Friday, 8 November 1895 Wilhelm was reproducing earlier work using low output Lenard tubes, whereby fluorescence was visible on a screen coated with barium platinocyanide. He moved on to a higher output Hittorf-Crookes tube, and reproduced the same phenomenon on a screen located near the tube. What he noticed, while in the darkened room, was similar fluorescence arising from another barium platinocyanide-coated screen over a meter away, far further than cathode ray tubes were known to work.
  • Despite moving the screen even further, fluorescence was still visible Enraptured in the thrill of discovery he worked through the night, and soon noticed that these new rays seemed to effortlessly pass through many objects opaque to visible light (e.g. books), but were blocked by metal objects, their outline visible on the screen.
  • While holding such an object he noted the outline of the bones of his hand. As the nature of the rays were unknown, he called them x-rays.

Reference: Yochum and Rowe's essentials of clinical radiology, third edition pg xxvii

questions.text: How does air look on CT?
questions.solution: Reference: Greenway, K., Bell, D. Hounsfield unit. Reference article, Radiopaedia.org. (accessed on 25 Mar 2022) https://doi.org/10.53347/rID-38181

questions.text: A patient suspected to have a motor vehicle accident and having brain injury was brought to hospital. What is the first line investigation?
questions.solution:
• Because of its wide availability and rapid detection of acute haemorrhage, CT is now accepted as the worldwide screening tool for imaging acute head trauma.
  • CT depicts both bone and soft tissue injuries. It is also widely accessible, fast, effective, and comparatively inexpensive.

Reference: Osborn Brain edition 2 page 6

questions.text: Which of the following modalities produce images that are in vivo equivalent to pictures of a cadaver?
questions.solution:
• In addition to the 5 categories of density, air, fat, water (includes soft tissue and muscle), calcium, and metal detected by plain films, CT scans are able to detect the differences between water and a variety of specific soft tissues including liver and kidneys and in the case of the brain, between white and gray matter.
  • CT provides detailed anatomic images in which a variety of soft tissues can be recognized; the resulting basic trans-axial images are the in vivo equivalent of trans-axial anatomic pictures of a cadaver.

Reference: Jacobson FL, McKean SC. Chapter 105. Introduction to Radiology. In: McKean SC, Ross JJ, Dressler DD, Brotman DJ, Ginsberg JS. eds. Principles and Practice of Hospital Medicine.

questions.text: A patient with blunt abdominal trauma is brought to a hospital. Which of the following investigation is to be done?
questions.solution:
• Focused abdominal sonography for trauma (FAST) has become an accepted screening modality for intraabdominal injuries in the traumatized patient.19-23 he primary focus of this limited study is to detect free intraperitoneal fluid with ultrasound in the trauma center.
  • Fluid detected in this setting strongly suggests significant intraabdominal injury requiring urgent laparotomy. FAST has replaced peritoneal lavage in many centers.

Reference: Focused Assessment with Sonography in Trauma (FAST) in 2017: What Radiologists Can Learn, John R. Richards and John P. McGahan, Radiology 2017 283:1, 30-48.

questions.text: What does A-mode ultrasound show?
questions.solution:
• The earliest A-mode devices displayed the voltage produced across the transducer by the backscattered echo as a vertical deflection on the face of an oscilloscope. The horizontal time sweep of the oscilloscope was calibrated to indicate the distance from the transducer to the reflecting surface.
  • In this form of display, the strength or amplitude of the reflected sound is indicated by the height of the vertical deflection displayed on the oscilloscope. With A-mode ultrasound, only the position and strength of a reflecting structure are recorded.

Reference: Christensen's Physics of diagnostic radiology page pg 341

questions.text: B-mode ultrasound produces which type of images?
questions.solution:
• The mainstay of imaging with ultrasound is provided by real-time, gray-scale, B-mode display, in which variations in display intensity or brightness are used to indicate reflected signals of different amplitude.
  • To generate a 2-D image, multiple ultrasound pulses are sent down a series of successive scan lines building a 2-D representation of echoes arising from the object being scanned.
  • When an ultrasound image is displayed on a black background, signals of greatest intensity appear as white; absence of signal is shown as black; and signals of intermediate intensity appear as shades of gray.
  • If the ultrasound beam is moved with respect to the object being examined and the position of the reflected signal is stored, the brightest portions of the resulting 2-D image indicate structures reflecting more of the transmitted sound energy back to the transducer.

Reference: Christensen's Physics of diagnostic radiology page pg 342

questions.text: Long TR and long TE gives ___ images.
questions.solution:
To produce T1 weighted images, TR and TE are kept short.

To produce T2 weighted images, TR and TE are kept long.

To produce proton density images, TR is kept long and TE is kept short.

Reference: MRI made easy page 12

questions.text: Identify the structure pointed in the image
questions.solution:
• The structure in the above image represents the Posterior cruciate ligament of the knee joint.
  • The posterior cruciate ligament, as its name suggests, is located posterior to the anterior cruciate ligament and is thicker and stronger than its anterior counterpart.
  • This robust ligament attaches to the posterior intercondylar area of the tibia and extends anteromedially and proximally to attach on to the lateral surface of the medial femoral condyle.

Reference: Musculoskeletal MRI, second edition page 368

questions.text: Identify the muscle
questions.solution:
• The given image shows a shoulder joint.
  • The muscle marked in the image is Supraspinatus. Supraspinatus is the smallest of the 4 muscles which comprise the Rotator Cuff of the shoulder joint specifically in the supraspinatus fossa.
  • It travels underneath the acromion. Supraspinatus fossa of the scapula. A shallow depression in the body of the scapula above its spine. It is inserted to the greater tuberosity of the humerus, superior facet.

Reference: Musculoskeletal MRI, second edition page 178

questions.text: A patient presented with deformities of the hands since 2 years. He/ she complaints of pain in hands since few days on waking up. An xray was taken which is shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Given x-ray shows hitchhiker thumb deformity. This is commonly seen in rheumatoid arthritis.

Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is a chronic multisystem disease with predominant musculoskeletal manifestations. RA is a synovial based process, with a predilection for:

  • PIP and MCP joints (especially 2nd and 3rd MCP)
  • ulnar styloid
  • Triquetrum

As a rule, the DIP joints are spared.

Late changes include:

  • subchondral cyst formation: the destruction of cartilage presses synovial fluid into the bone
  • subluxation causing:
    • ulnar deviation of the MCP joints
    • boutonniere and swan neck deformities
  • hitchhiker's thumb deformity
  • carpal instability: scapholunate dissociation, ulnar translocation
  • ankylosis
  • scallop sign: erosion of the ulnar aspect of the distal radius which may be predictive of extensor tendon rupture (Vaughan-Jackson syndrome)
  • pencil-in-cup deformity: classically psoriatic arthropathy but well-recognized in rheumatoid arthritis.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 2487

questions.text: 60-year-old male patient complaints of backache and difficulty in bending forward. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The given x-ray shows calcification of the posterior longitudinal ligament as evidenced by radio-opaque linear opacity in the midline.
  • Ankylosing spondylitis (less commonly known as Bechterew disease or Marie Strümpell disease) is a seronegative spondyloarthropathy, which results in fusion (ankylosis) of the spine and sacroiliac (SI) joints.
  • Early spondylitis is characterized by small erosions at the corners of vertebral bodies with reactive sclerosis:
    • Romanus lesions of the spine (shiny corner sign)
    • vertebral body squaring
    • Non-infectious spondylodiscitis: Andersson lesion
    • Diffuse syndesmophytic ankylosis can give a 'bamboo spine' appearance
      • Syndesmophytes are classically described as paravertebral ossification running parallel to the spine
    • Linear ossification along the central spine; representing interspinous ligament ossification can give a 'dagger spine' appearance on frontal radiographs;
    • Ossification of spinal ligaments, joints and discs (with fatty marrow within the ossified disc, best seen on MRI)
    • Apophyseal and costovertebral arthritis and ankylosis
    • Enthesophyte formation from enthesopathy
    • Pseudoarthroses may form at fracture sites
    • Dural ectasia

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 2831

questions.text: Identify the type of fracture being shown in the image below
questions.solution:
Given image shows a fracture of shaft of tibia and fibula. There is evidence of irregularity of the fracture margins and sclerosis of the margins. This shows that a this is an old process. This help in making the diagnosis as non-united fracture.

Some radiographic features of non-united fracture are as follows:

  • hypertrophic: abundant callus formation; radiolucent line (unmineralized fibrocartilage) at the non-union site
  • oligotrophic: little or no callus formation; diastasis at the fracture site
  • atrophic: bony surfaces partially resorbed; no callus formation; osteopenia; sclerotic avascular bone segments; segmental bone loss
  • infected: osteolysis; osteopenia; sclerotic avascular bone segments; segmental bone loss
  • synovial pseudoarthrosis: variable appearance (hypertrophic, oligotrophic, or atrophic)

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 3970

questions.text: Identify the type of fracture
questions.solution:
• The given image shows a uni-cortical break of the bones of hand. This is known as green stick fracture.
  • Greenstick fractures are incomplete fractures of long bones and are usually seen in young children, more commonly less than 10 years of age. They are commonly mid-diaphyseal, affecting the forearm and lower leg.
  • Features on plain radiograph
  • usually mid-diaphyseal
  • occur in tandem with angulation
  • Incomplete fracture, with cortical breach of only one side of the bone

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 982

questions.text: Which of the following artery is used in obstetrics doppler for twin twin transfusion syndrome?
questions.solution:
In current clinical practice, the S/D ratio and the presence of absent or reversed end-diastolic flow are used to manage fetal growth restriction and to stage the twin-twin transfusion syndrome.

Reference: A Radiologist's Guide to the Performance and Interpretation of Obstetric Doppler US Anne M. Kennedy and Paula J. Woodward RadioGraphics 2019 39:3, 893-910

questions.text: What does S wave in the following image represent?
questions.solution:
• Ductus venosus waveform in two different fetuses. A = A wave (atrial contraction), D = D wave (ventricular diastole), S = S wave (ventricular systole).
  • Reversal of the A wave is always abnormal.
  • Associations include increased risk of aneuploidy and congenital heart disease; and in twins, reversal of the A wave is a marker for increased risk of developing the twin-twin transfusion syndrome.
  • Abnormal findings include the absence or reversal of the A wave.

Reference: A Radiologist's Guide to the Performance and Interpretation of Obstetric Doppler US

Anne M. Kennedy and Paula J. Woodward

RadioGraphics 2019 39:3, 893-910

choices.text: Fracture line which crosses the carotid canal
Facet subluxation on CT cervical spine

questions.text: Which of the following injuries does not require evaluation by angiography?
questions.solution:
• Cranio-cervical CTA should also specifically be considered
    1. in the setting of penetrating neck injury,
    2. if a fractured foramen transversarium or facet subluxation is identified on cervical spine CT, or
    3. if a skull base fracture traverses the carotid canal or a dural venous sinus.
  • Arterial laceration or dissection, traumatic pseudoaneurysm, carotid-cavernous fistula, or dural venous sinus injury are nicely depicted on high-resolution CTA.

Reference: Osborn Brain edition 2 page 7

questions.text: What is shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
• Cardiac tamponade is the result of an accumulation of fluid, pus, blood, gas, or benign or malignant neoplastic tissue within the pericardial cavity, which can occur either rapidly or gradually over time, but eventually, results in impaired cardiac output.
  • This is to be distinguished from a pericardial effusion, which can be very large but does not necessarily impair cardiac function.
  • Chest radiographs may show cardiomegaly with or without an epicardial fat pad sign suggesting a pericardial effusion.
  • Echocardiography is considered the gold standard, and commonly first line, imaging modality for assessment of cardiac tamponade. This is due to its ability to provide detailed structural and functional information about the heart, pericardium, and inferior vena cava (IVC). It also allows approach planning for pericardiocentesis.

Reference: Radswiki, T., Sharma, R. Cardiac tamponade. Reference article, Radiopaedia.org. https://doi.org/10.53347/rID-12376

questions.text: Identify the injury
questions.solution:
• Urethral injuries can result in long-term morbidity and most commonly result from trauma. The male urethra is much more commonly injured than the female urethra
  • In the setting of trauma, the classic triad of blood of the external urethral meatus or vaginal introitus may be seen but is an unreliable sign, as is haematuria. Inability to void may be seen in complete urethral disruption. Examination may reveal blood on digital rectal exam and perineal ecchymosis.
  • Voiding cystourethrography is the most appropriate way to evaluate the posterior part of the male urethra and injuries to the female urethra. Retrograde urethrography is the modality of choice to investigate the anterior part of the urethra. It will demonstrate extraluminal contrast, which has extravasated from the urethra at the site of injury. It is important to determine if this is above the urogenital diaphragm (anterior) or below (posterior) it. Patients with incomplete injuries may represent subsequently with strictures.

Reference: Knipe, H., Hacking, C. Urethral injury. Reference article, Radiopaedia.org. https://doi.org/10.53347/rID-31812

questions.text: A patient presented to emergency department with severe vomiting and blood in stools. He underwent a USG of abdomen. The image is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows target sign which is seen in intussusception in paediatric patients. In intussusception, there is bowel within bowel appearance giving rise to a target sign on cross sectional imaging.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 1144

questions.text: Identify the following
questions.solution:
• The given barium image shows a distended esophagus followed by thinning of the contrast column of the barium giving a rat tail appearance.
  • This is known as rat tail sign and is suggestive of achlasia cardia.
  • Achlasia cardia is a motility disorder of the GEJ in which there is improper contraction of the GEJ which leads to incomplete emptying of the esophagus and it's progressive dilation.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 2407

questions.text:
A patient presented with a cystic lesion in the liver on USG which is shown below.

It was diagnosed as a case of liver abscess. What is another expected finding in such patient suspected to have amoebic liver abscess?
questions.solution:
Hepatic abscesses are localized collections of necrotic inflammatory tissue caused by bacterial, parasitic, or fungal agents. Hepatic abscesses can occur via different routes such as:

  • hematogenous spread of infection via the portal vein or hepatic arteries
  • biliary spread of infection from ascending cholangitis or cholecystitis
  • direct inoculation in the setting of penetrating trauma or iatrogenic following a procedure

In developing countries, parasitic abscesses are the most common hence ileocaecal junction and caecum should be evaluated to find out the amoebic involvement.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page 1890

questions.text: Identify the organ marked in the image given below.
questions.solution:
• The gallbladder is a pear-shaped Musculo-membranous sac located along the under-surface of the liver.
  • It functions to accumulate and concentrate bile between meals.
  • The normal adult gallbladder measures from 7-10 cm in length and 3-4 cm in transverse diameter.
  • The gallbladder is closely apposed to the liver within the fossa.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page 1972

questions.text: A patient presented with sudden onset of right upper quadrant pain and fever. On doing an USG, the following image was obtained of liver and gallbladder. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Acute cholecystitis refers to the acute inflammation of the gallbladder. It is the primary complication of cholelithiasis and the most common cause of acute pain in the right upper quadrant (RUQ).
  • The most sensitive US finding in acute cholecystitis is the presence of cholelithiasis in combination with the sonographic Murphy sign. Both gallbladder wall thickening (>3 mm) and pericholecystic fluid are secondary findings.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page 1979

questions.text: Which of the following is the investigation of choice for gall stones?
questions.solution:
• Transabdominal ultrasound (TAUS) is the gold standard test for the diagnosis of gallstone disease.
  • The following result of transabdominal ultrasound is confirmatory of gallstone disease:
  • Solitary or multiple stones in the gallbladder or another site within the biliary tree.
  • Sludge or gravel seen within the gall-bladder. It should be performed when the patient presented with symptoms/signs of abdominal pain, jaundice and fever.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page 1972

questions.text: 'Chain of lakes appearance' is seen in?
questions.solution:
• Chronic pancreatitis represents the end result of a continuous, prolonged, inflammatory, and fibrosing process that affects the pancreas. The most common cause of chronic pancreatitis in adults is excessive alcohol consumption.
  • On MRI, features of chronic pancreatitis can be divided into early and late findings:
  • early findings
    • low-signal-intensity pancreas on T1-weighted fat-suppressed images
    • decreased and delayed enhancement after IV contrast administration
    • dilated side branches
  • late findings
    • parenchymal atrophy or enlargement
    • pseudocyst formation
    • dilatation and beading of the pancreatic duct often with intraductal calcifications, could give a 'chain of lakes' appearance.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page 2032

questions.text: What is seen in the image below?
questions.solution:
Spigelian hernias involve protrusion of omental fat, bowel, or other intra-abdominal contents through a defect in the Spigelian aponeurosis, located along the lateral margin of the rectus abdominis muscle at the semi-lunar line.

  • This type of hernia has become more common as laparoscopic port sites are often placed in this location.
  • They most commonly occur in middle-aged adults, but can present at any age, including in children.
  • A Spigelian hernia may present as an incidental, asymptomatic finding, with slight swelling or localized pain, or as a frank bowel obstruction.
  • The abdominal contents may protrude into the subcutaneous fat, but commonly dissect between the internal and external oblique muscles. It is important in cases of bowel obstruction to look for associated signs of bowel strangulation (i.e. circumferentially thickened bowel wall, pneumatosis intestinalis, free fluid, or absent or decreased bowel wall enhancement).

Reference: Gastrointestinal Imaging Cases, Angela D. Levy, Koenraad J. Mortele, and Benjamin M. Yeh; page 360

questions.text: First line imaging modality for evaluation of renal transplant dysfunction is:
questions.solution:
• According to American College of Radiology appropriateness criteria for renal transplant dysfunction, US duplex Doppler is the first line investigation.
  • Colour doppler is used to evaluate the status of graft vessels and to detect any areas of focal stenosis or thrombosis. Colour doppler is also primary diagnostic modality for identifying various vascular complications.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 179

questions.text: A patient presented to OPD with complaints of hematuria. He underwent an IVP study which is shown below, what is the most probable diagnosis.
questions.solution:
Given IVP image shows filling defect in urinary bladder shown by arrow. The whole urinary bladder is opacified by contrast except the area of filling defect. This feature is highly suggestive of urinary bladder carcinoma which is endophytic and grows into the urinary bladder.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 206

questions.text: Which of the following is not a radiological sign of chronic kidney disease?
questions.solution:
Chronic kidney disease occurs due to chronic process over years and as a result of necrosis or fibrosis results in small sized kidneys, increase in cortical echogenicity and loss of corticomedullary differentiation

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 70

questions.text: Identify the most probable diagnosis
questions.solution:
• Given image of IVP shows adderhead appearance of the ureters which is highly suggestive of ureterocele.
  • This occurs as there is a membrane between the ureteric opening and bladder and on giving contrast there is pooling of contrast at the lower end and contrast does not pass to the bladder, thus giving the adderhead appearance.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 58

questions.text: 'Pipe stem ureter' is seen in?
questions.solution:
• Pipe stem ureter is a finding of tuberculosis of ureter in which the ureter becomes shortened, rigid inflexible and with narrow lumen.
  • This leads to a characteristic appearance of pipe stem ureter.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 97 (table 1)

questions.text: Three phase bone scan is done in?
questions.solution:
• Three phase bone scan is done in osteomyelitis.
  • Characteristic finding in osteomyelitis in a 'three-phase bone scan' is increased activity in the blood flow and pool phases and intense focal uptake in the involved bone in the delayed phase.
  • Scintigraphy is especially useful early on when radiographic abnormalities are not evident, and initiation of early treatment prevents irreversible bone damage.
  • Sensitivity greater than 90% is described in several series for diagnosis of osteomyelitis.

Reference: Mc-Graw Hill speciality Board review Radiology page 726

questions.text: The average photon energy produced by the Cobalt-60 isotope is?
questions.solution:
• Traditionally, telecobalt units using Co-60 as the source of radiation has been used in most of the centres in developing countries.
  • The decay half-life of cobalt is 5.26 years and average photon energy is 1.25 MeV.
  • Though simple in operation and easy to maintain, these units are limited by the periodic need to replace the radioactive source and disposal of the used source.

Reference: Mehta, SR & Suhag, Virender & Semwal, Manoj & Sharma, Neelam. (2010). Radiotherapy: Basic Concepts and Recent Advances. Medical Journal Armed Forces India. 66. 158-162. 10.1016/S0377-1237(10)80132-7 page 3
